questions.question: Calculate the momentum of a 450 g soccer ball traveling at a velocity of 22.0 m/s toward the north.
Which has a greater magnitude of momentum: a 0.015 kg hummingbird flying at 12.0 m/s or a 0.1 kg toy car rolling at 1.5 m/s?
questions.explanation: Hummingbird: $p = 0.015 \times 12 = 0.18$ kg·m/s. Toy car: $p = 0.1 \times 1.5 = 0.15$ kg·m/s. Hummingbird has greater momentum.

questions.question: A 2,400 kg truck has a momentum of 36,000 kg·m/s. Determine the velocity of the truck in meters per second.
An object with a mass of 6.0 kg has a velocity vector with components $v_x = 4.0 \text{ m/s}$ and $v_y = -3.0 \text{ m/s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the object's total momentum.
A 2.0 kg projectile is moving such that its horizontal momentum is 8.0 kg·m/s and its vertical momentum is 6.0 kg·m/s. Determine the angle of the projectile's velocity relative to the horizontal.
Which of the following statements about momentum is true?
options: It is only dependent on velocity
It is conserved in isolated systems
Heavier objects always have less momentum than lighter objects
questions.explanation: Momentum is conserved in isolated systems (no external forces).

questions.question: Which example correctly illustrates the conservation of momentum?
options: A truck colliding with a wall and shattering it
Two ice skaters pushing away from each other
A car rolling to a stop at constant deceleration
A ball thrown upwards against the influence of gravity
questions.explanation: Two ice skaters pushing away from each other is a classic isolated system where momentum is conserved.

questions.question: If an object's mass doubles while maintaining the same velocity, what happens to its momentum?
questions.explanation: $p = mv$, so doubling mass doubles momentum.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the relationship between momentum and kinetic energy?
options: Both are conserved in all interactions
Momentum is a vector, while kinetic energy is a scalar
Kinetic energy depends on mass only, while momentum depends on velocity only
questions.explanation: Momentum is a vector; KE is a scalar. This is a key difference.

questions.question: How does the direction of momentum relate to that of velocity?
options: They are always opposite to each other
Momentum has the same direction as velocity
They are always perpendicular to each other
questions.explanation: $\vec{p} = m\vec{v}$, so momentum has the same direction as velocity.
